required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Endotracheal Intracuff Pressure Between Two Cuff Sealing Methods
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Endotracheal Intracuff Pressure Between Two Cuff Sealing Methods

brief_summary.textblock: The endotracheal intracuff pressure is to be maintained at a low level to prevent trachea and nerve damages, and yet be high enough to secure air sealing. The objective of the study is to compare minimal occlusive volume technique (MOVT) and expired volume/inspired volume ratio (VE/VI ratio) from a spirometer method of endotracheal tube (ETT) cuff inflation with respect to the cuff pressure required to seal the airway during a laparoscopic surgery under general anesthesia. A study design is a randomized crossover trial in 35 patients. The primary outcome is the intracuff pressure of an endotracheal tube. The study consists of two cuff sealing methods separated by a period of 10 minutes.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Two methods of cuff sealing will be applied in a random sequence to each patient.
study_design_info.masking_description: The randomization table of a treatment sequence will be managed by the third person who will not involve in this study.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From the start of cuff inflation to the airway sealing, an average of 2 minutes
primary_outcome.description: The intracuff pressure of endotracheal tube when cuff sealing is achieved.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From the start of cuff inflation to the airway sealing, an average of 2 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The intracuff air volume of endotracheal tube when cuff sealing is achieved.

arm_group.description: MOVT (minimal occlusive volume technique). The cuff sealing will be confirmed with MOVT, then the intracuff pressure will be measured.
VE/VI ratio of Spirometer. The cuff sealing will be confirmed with VE/VI ratio of a spirometer, then the intracuff pressure will be measured.

intervention.description: ETT cuff will be inflated till the disappearance of audible air leak on auscultation, while abdominal carbon dioxide (CO2) inflation is maintained with peak inspiratory pressure of 25 cm H2O during volume controlled ventilation. The patient will be in the Trendelenburg position.

ETT cuff will be inflated till the VE/VI ratio meets the initial VE/VI ratio, while abdominal CO2 inflation is maintained with peak inspiratory pressure of 25 cm H2O during volume controlled ventilation. The patient will be in the Trendelenburg position.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status I, II
- Body mass index ï¼œ 30 kg/m2
- Elective laparoscopic gynecologic surgery under general anesthesia in the Trendelenburg position
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of airway-related or pulmonary diseases/abnormalities
- When difficult intubation is anticipated
- History of general anesthesia within the past 3 months
- Pregnancy
- History of smoking

facility.name: Dept. of anesthesiology and pain medicine, Dongguk University Ilsan Hospital
